awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Alteration of microbially-produced carbonate rock by unicellular predators to better understand early Earth's dominant ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
Collaborative Research: Alteration of microbially-produced carbonate rock by unicellular predators to better understand early Earth's dominant ecosystem

How Earth transitioned from a microbe-dominated Precambrian world to the Phanerozoic Era with complex multicellular life is a continuing geological and biological riddle. Studying living microbialites (carbonate rocks built by microbes, ancient counterparts of coral reefs) in Fayetteville Green Lake, NY, will help solve this riddle. This interdisciplinary study will reveal how the internal structure of these living rocks is formed by microbes and how it is altered by the action of microscopic unicellular predators (so-called protists). Understanding the role of protists in living examples will help to decipher microbialites in the rock record, ultimately improving understanding of the evolution of life on early Earth. The petroleum industry seeks to improve understanding of microbialites' microstructure. The discovery of large subsalt reservoirs off the coast of Brazil, Congo, Eritrea and in the US Gulf of Mexico challenged oil companies to understand the record of very deep (~1-2 km thick) fossil microbialites present underneath an equally thick salt layer. This project will increase the understanding of fabric porosity, and reservoir rocks, critical factors in decision-making during oil exploration. The major outreach activity will be a Science through Art traveling exhibition related to microbialite ecosystems and predation on early Earth, with a tentative title of "Decimation of Slime World" (in other words, predation of microbialites). This theme will generate wide interest, and will offer explanations about the research findings in ways that would otherwise escape the art-loving public sector.

The oldest fossil microbialites are the most visible manifestations of microbial life on early Earth. Comprehension of structural differences between microbialite types (e.g., clotted thrombolites, laminated stromatolites) is hampered by incomplete knowledge of their microbiology and early diagenesis. Prokaryotic diversity in extant marine microbialites is well established, however, until recently heterotrophic protists inhabiting these structures and their impact on mesofabric were unknown. A comparative study of non-marine microbialites is lacking. Fayetteville Green Lake NY (FGL), a Proterozoic ocean analog, supports extant microbialites in a non-marine setting. Investigations will assess the role of eukaryotes, notably protists, in microbialite fabric modification and in the possible transition from laminated to clotted mesofabrics during early diagenesis. Four hypotheses will be addressed using FGL materials with these specific aims: 1. Assess biodiversity and activities in microbialites and non-microbialite habitats via sequencing, Fluorescently Labeled Embedded Core method, and various microscopy methods. 2. Determine biogeochemistry using microelectrodes and major in situ microbial activities to link microbiota, element distribution, and mesofabric. 3. Obtain microbialite mesofabric information using microCT scanning. 4. Combine SEM-EDS and Synchrotron-based microXRF to analyze mesofabric features, especially clots, for presence of pyrite and biogenic metals. 5. Determine impact of foraminifera on microbialite mesofabric using seeding experiment. 6. Perform ?forced diagenesis? by incubating microbialite samples under elevated pressure/temperature, inspecting changes in mesofabric using SEM, µCT and µXRF scanning. 7. Use SEM and petrographic thin sections to examine relict thrombolite mesofabric for former eukaryote activity/presence.

por.por_cntn:
In our collaborative multidisciplinary project, we studied biogeochemical aspects of the unusual geologic feature manifest as Deadman's Point in Green Lake, located near Fayetteville, New York (USA; hereafter "FGL").  Deadman's Point has a rather extensive shallow limestone "platform" extending into the lake approximately 45 feet and running along the shoreline approximately 180 ft. The water depth of this platform depends on rainfall, but is generally between a few cm to 1 m in depth; the platform is easily visible from the public trail around the lake. The limestone platform is capped by "microbialites", which are formed by binding and trapping of sediment grains as well as via production of mineral precipitates by microbes near the surface of the structure. The fine-scale (mm) form of microbialites can vary: layered forms are called "stromatolites", clotted forms "thrombolites", and unstructured forms "leiolites".  Microbialites develop in hypersaline, marine and freshwater environments, including FGL, a moderately alkaline setting that has been considered an analog to Earth's early oceans, before animals evolved. Microbialites are Earth's first extensive, easily visible evidence of life, and abundantly present as fossils in the rock record. Studying living examples of early life forms provides insights into early Earth?s ecosystem functioning and environment, but microbialites in lakes are understudied. We studied key issues related to how the unique FGL platform is formed and altered over the seasons and across years.  In particular, we studied carbonate precipitation, at the microscale, and fabric alteration, at the mesoscale, in the FGL microbialites. 

To assess microbialite formation, one focus was determining the type of photosynthetic microbes (cyanobacteria) that dominated the microbialite; this was accomplished by culturing coccoid (roundish) and filamentous (chain-like) cyanobacteria in lake waters to determine their respective limestone formation rates. Findings revealed that calcium carbonate precipitation was higher in coccoid cultures than in filamentous ones, which is contrary to some results from prior investigations. 

Because the FGL microbialites change over time, another focus involved assessment of the lake water-column physicochemical parameters and platform ecosystem composition and activities over time. Measurements conducted by us over 14 trips over 5 years included, but were not limited to, oxygen, nutrients, pH, and amount of carbonate. Also, we assessed the microbial and eukaryotic diversity, via DNA sequencing, in combination with key metabolic processes over a growth season of the community at the surface of the platform and compared this with the major geochemical changes in the water column. Changes in the chemistry of the water column favor limestone production in late summer, but the microbes in the platform are most active in the fall with respect to platform growth. Calcium carbonate particles are trapped by microbes early in the year and produced toward the end of the year, adding small amounts of rock to the platform.

In the context of microbialite change over time, one focus was determining the role of pseudopodial-bearing protists (single-celled eukaryotes) in altering the layered (stromatolite) fabric at the microbialite surface into a clotted fabric present at depth. Such disruption had been noted previously by marine protists (foraminifera) on marine stromatolites. If this could be demonstrated, the role of protists in the transition of stromatolites (layered) to thrombolites (clotted) would have additional support and the appearance of thrombolites in the rock record (about 2 billion years ago) could be implicated by the evolution of these early-evolving eukaryotes. Our experiments did not, however, show that pseudopodia-bearing protists greatly impacted the FGL microbialite microstructure. We did, however, identify a freshwater pseudopodia-bearing protist that inhabits the FGL microbialite platform. We also documented the occurrence of this protist in their living position in the microbialites. 

Because few experiments have assessed microbialite ?aging? or lithification into the geological record, we also exposed FGL microbialites to relatively high pressures and temperatures to mimic what occurs during early diagenesis. In sum, our collective study is of interest and importance to a wide variety of disciplines, such as biogeochemistry, microbiology, evolutionary biology, benthic ecology, paleontology, and paleoclimatology.

Our main broader impact effort was a Science-Through-Art effort that embedded an early-career artist / illustrator into our project. This artist joined two of our collection outings to learn how science was performed in the field; she also visited our shore-based laboratory to view the microbial world in person via microscopy. Her resulting artworks interpreted the time on Earth when microbialites were widespread, the foraminifer-like microbial world, and the different morphologies of the FGL microbialites. The artist has since begun graduate school in scientific illustration.
